utterances: I don't know how we, the business community, could relate to their specific concern.
Other leading business groups, including The Business Roundtable and National Federation of Independent Business, have no plans to get involved in the Supreme Court debate.
So for now the K Street lobbyists will sidestep the battle at hand, the one within the conservative world of the GOP.
And they'll hope Miers' nomination survives to the next stage, where they can engage in the traditional work of wooing lawmakers.
Peter Overby, NPR News, the Capitol.
Now, President Trump says he spoke with his CIA director and the secretary of state yesterday to get briefed by - about Jamal Khashoggi.
While touring fire damage in California, the president maintained, ""The CIA hasn't assessed anything yet."" That's a quote.
Joining us now to talk about the president's response to this and more is national political correspondent Mara Liasson.
Good morning.
Good morning.
So as we've mentioned, The Washington Post and others are reporting that the CIA has concluded that Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman ordered the killing of Jamal Khashoggi.
But the president basically said that he doesn't believe that's the case yet.
What's going on?
Well, one thing that's interesting is that the intelligence community would leak this information.
It's almost as if they're concerned the president wouldn't accept it.
And they have to make it public.
Of course, they said they have high confidence that the crown prince ordered the death of Khashoggi.
And the president refusing to accept this is a little bit like what he did with Russian interference in the 2016 elections.
After his intelligence community confirmed one thing, he just didn't want to believe it.
Now, he says that even if this is true, there are other important reasons to preserve our close ties with Saudi Arabia, like oil and jobs in the Middle East.

He did say that there would be a full report from the White House on Tuesday to determine, quote, ""who caused it."" But we know that he's been told about this intelligence because he was briefed by the CIA director.
...you know, what the place actually carries is what I actually go to do, and it's the people there that I go to play for.
Well, none of them is really perfect, but I think now I probably will lean towards President Obama.
We decided to pit DJ Cuzzin B against a gamer - NPR intern Brian Reardon.
You're overthinking it.
You've just got to move it - just moving it back and forth.
Oh.
Yeah, I'm overthinking it.
I'm at NPR, not the club.
(Soundbite of laughter)
DJ Cuzzin B was experiencing the same problems some guitar players have with Guitar Hero.
Real skills don't translate.
They confuse you.
That's weird, because you normally don't scratch with just one finger.
So it's really strange.
But okay.
When FreeStyle Games first developed DJ Hero, creative director Jamie Jackson asked regular people what they thought DJs did.
Ninety-nine percent of them put one hand to their ear and the other made a scratching sound and kind of went wika, wika, wika.
(Soundbite of turntable scratching)
See, I don't know anything about turntables, and I'm sure like - like I have no idea what this - I've never known what guys are doing when they do that.
Gamer Brian Reardon still utterly destroys the DJ in this virtual battle.
Robert Carter is a fabulous DJ in real life.
He's not fabulous at scoring points in the game's glamorous industrial nightclub.
You are just stinking up the joint.
They just booed me.
Oh, you didn't even get one star.
I didn't get a star, man.
They booed me.
Is there anything about this that's like actual DJ-ing?
DJs fantasize for an environment like this.
You have about 30,000 people out there going crazy.
I mean, everybody's reacting - no fights out there.
DJ Cuzzin B, a.k.a.
Robert Carter, says this game is perfect if you want to one-up a DJ.
Say, man, you know what?
I think you would be nice at DJ Hero.
Let me check you out.
And then you just kill them.
Still, Carter plans to get the game for his little eight-year-old nephew.
In a few years, he says, he'll teach him how to DJ for real.
Neda Ulaby, NPR News.
Assisted suicide advocate Jack Kevorkian is dead at age 83.
Supporters say he was a compassionate caregiver who paid a steep price for helping chronically and terminally ill patients end their suffering.
Critics say Kevorkian's zealotry clouded his ability to behave like a responsible physician.
Sarah Hulett of Michigan Radio has this remembrance.
Jack Kevorkian claimed to have assisted in the suicides of 130 people with the help of machines he invented.
He called one the Thanatron or death machine, and another the Merictron or mercy machine.
Journalist Jack Lessenberry wrote about Kevorkian for The New York Times and Vanity Fair.
It'll be very interesting 50 years from now to see whether Kevorkian is regarded by history as this sort of bizarre crank, or whether he was regarded as a modern medical pioneer.
I think we simply don't know.
Kevorkian first captured the public's attention in 1990.
That's when Janet Adkins climbed into the back of his VW van in a suburban Detroit park, laid down and waited as Kevorkian put a needle into her arm.
Adkins pushed a button on a machine and released a painkiller and a poison that killed her quickly and spared her from a future with Alzheimer's disease.
After a string of acquittals through the 1990s, a newly-elected prosecutor said he didn't plan to bring charges against Kevorkian in any more cases.
And the right-to-die cause was gaining traction nationally.
But in 1998, Kevorkian helped Tom Youk, who had Lou Gehrig's disease, commit suicide.
Kevorkian then sent a video to the news program ""60 Minutes.
Tom, do you want to go ahead with this?
Yes.
Shake your head yes if you want to go.
The difference this time was that instead of the patient pushing the button, Kevorkian administered the lethal injection.
And we're ready to inject.
We're going to inject in your right arm.
A couple of my top administrators were at my house, we were watching the TV.
We all looked at it and I said, oh, you know what, this is going to be a bigger headache than we thought.
That's David Gorcyca.
He was the Oakland County prosecutor at the time of the broadcast.
He, on ""60 Minutes,"" said what more does he - meaning I - need to prosecute me.
So he was begging me to prosecute.
Kevorkian was charged.
He decided to represent himself at trial, and a jury convicted him of murder.
Journalist Jack Lessenberry says Kevorkian believed his conviction would be a catalyst for the right-to-die movement.
What he thought was once he was convicted, people would surround the prison and demand his release and the world would be safe for euthanasia.
But as he - when he was convicted he looked at me, it was in the courtroom, he said I've got them right where I want them.
And they hustled him away.
And the prosecutor looked at me and said: Prisoners don't usually get to hold press conferences.
Kevorkian served eight years in prison.
Once he was released in 2007, he kept a relatively low profile.
He lectured some and was scheduled to start a book tour later this month.
But he went into the hospital a few weeks ago with pneumonia and kidney problems.
He died in the middle of the night after a blood clot from his leg traveled to his lungs.
Attorney Geoffrey Fieger represented Kevorkian for almost a decade.
He says the fact that his long-time client did not end his life in the same way he advocated, takes nothing away from the cause in which he believed.
